physics.principle: Polarization state is determined by the amplitude ratio and phase difference of two orthogonal electric field components
physics.principle_beginner: Imagine light is jumping rope - it can jump up and down (linear), spin in circles (circular), or draw ovals (elliptical). How it 'jumps' depends on how two waves combine - like two people coordinating a dance!
physics.principle_advanced: Any fully polarized state is precisely described by the Jones vector J = [Ex·e^(iδx), Ey·e^(iδy)]^T. The state's position on the Poincaré sphere is uniquely determined by Stokes parameters (S₁, S₂, S₃), satisfying S₀² = S₁² + S₂² + S₃².
details: When δ=0° or 180°, it is linearly polarized
When δ=90° and Ex=Ey, it is circularly polarized
Other cases are elliptically polarized
details_beginner: Linear: Light vibrates in one direction, like a guitar string
Circular: Light spirals as it travels, like a corkscrew
3D movies use circular polarization so tilting your head doesn't break the effect
details_advanced: The Poincaré sphere maps all polarization states to a 2-sphere surface
Orthogonal polarization states are antipodal points on the sphere
Polarization evolution through optical elements corresponds to rotations on the sphere

lifeScene.title: How 3D Glasses Really Work
lifeScene.title_advanced: Chiral Photon States in Stereoscopic Imaging
lifeScene.imageAlt: Cross-section showing 3D movie glasses with circular polarizers, one for left eye rotating clockwise, right eye counter-clockwise
lifeScene.hook: Your 3D movie glasses aren't just dark plastic - they contain sophisticated polarization technology that gives each eye a different image!
lifeScene.hook_beginner: Ever wonder how movies seem to jump out at you in 3D? It's all about special spinning light - and those funny glasses are the key!
lifeScene.hook_advanced: Modern stereoscopic displays exploit the orthogonality of left- and right-handed circular polarization states, utilizing quarter-wave retarders to encode independent visual channels.
facts: Modern 3D glasses use circular polarization - left eye sees clockwise, right eye sees counter-clockwise
The projector rapidly switches between two circularly polarized images
This is why you can tilt your head in 3D movies - circular polarization doesn't depend on angle
facts_beginner: Each lens in 3D glasses only lets spinning light from one direction through
Your left eye sees one picture, your right eye sees another - your brain puts them together for 3D!
Try tilting your head in a 3D movie - it still works because the light is spinning, not just wiggling
facts_advanced: RealD uses a Z-screen with alternating quarter-wave retardation at 144Hz refresh rate
Circular polarization eliminates ghost images caused by viewer head tilt (unlike linear polarization)
The handedness convention follows the right-hand rule applied to the wave propagation vector

diy.title: See the Spin in 3D Glasses
materials: RealD 3D glasses from a movie theater
A bright LCD screen (phone or computer)
steps: Look at the LCD screen through one lens - it looks normal
Now look at the REFLECTION of the screen in the mirror through the SAME lens
The screen should appear black or very dark!
Try the other lens - same effect but original screen is dark instead
diy.observation: Reflection reverses the circular polarization direction! Right-circular becomes left-circular. Each lens only passes one type, proving the glasses use circular polarization.

lifeScene.title: Your Phone Screen Uses This Physics
lifeScene.title_advanced: Electromagnetic Wave Projection in Anisotropic Media
lifeScene.imageAlt: Person wearing polarized sunglasses looking at smartphone screen, showing how tilting the phone causes screen to darken
lifeScene.hook: You spend 5+ hours daily looking at screens. Have you noticed your phone goes dark when you tilt it while wearing sunglasses?
lifeScene.hook_beginner: Want to see a magic trick? Grab some sunglasses and your phone - you can make the screen disappear just by tilting it!
lifeScene.hook_advanced: The intensity modulation in LCD displays represents a practical application of electromagnetic wave vector projection, governed by Malus's Law which describes photon absorption probability in dichroic media.
facts: Every LCD screen has two polarizers - without them, you'd see nothing but white light
Try wearing polarized sunglasses and rotating your phone 90° - the screen will go black!
Photographers use polarizing filters based on this same law to eliminate reflections
facts_beginner: Your phone screen is like a light sandwich with special filters on each side
Sunglasses + phone = cool magic trick! Rotate and watch the screen go dark
This same trick is why 3D movies work and why some people can see through water glare
facts_advanced: LCD extinction ratio typically exceeds 1000:1 due to precision alignment of polarizer axes
Crossed polarizers achieve near-perfect extinction, limited only by birefringent stress in the glass
Modern IPS panels use 178° viewing angles by optimizing the liquid crystal molecular twist

physics.principle: Malus's Law describes the intensity change when polarized light passes through a polarizer
physics.principle_beginner: A polarizer is like a fence with vertical slats - if light 'wiggles' vertically, it passes through; if it wiggles horizontally, it gets blocked. At an angle? Some gets through, some doesn't!
physics.principle_advanced: Malus's Law is a macroscopic manifestation of electromagnetic wave propagation in anisotropic media. From quantum electrodynamics, the photon polarization state projects onto the detector eigenstate, with detection probability |⟨ψ_detector|ψ_photon⟩|² = cos²θ.
details: θ is the angle between light polarization and polarizer axis
Maximum transmission when parallel (θ=0°)
Complete blocking when perpendicular (θ=90°)
details_beginner: At 45°, exactly half the light gets through (cos²45° = 0.5)
Two crossed polarizers (90° apart) block all light
This is how LCD screens control brightness - pixel by pixel!
details_advanced: The cos² dependence arises from projecting the electric field vector onto the polarizer axis
Sequential polarizers follow multiplicative intensity reduction
Quantum mechanically, a single photon either passes or is absorbed - cos²θ is the probability

diy.title: Two-Sunglasses Experiment
materials: Two pairs of polarized sunglasses (or polarizing film from old 3D glasses)
A bright light source (lamp or phone flashlight)

steps: Hold one pair of sunglasses up to the light - note the brightness
Now hold the second pair behind the first, aligned the same way - similar brightness
Slowly rotate one pair 90° - watch the light completely disappear!
Try angles in between (30°, 45°, 60°) and notice the gradual change
diy.observation: At 45° rotation, light is reduced to 50% - exactly as Malus's Law predicts (cos²45° = 0.5)

This is why modern 3D is comfortable - no need to keep your head perfectly level

lifeScene.title: The Lake at Sunset Mystery
lifeScene.imageAlt: Split comparison: lakeside view at noon showing visible fish vs same lake at sunset showing perfect mirror reflection
lifeScene.hook: Why can you see fish clearly when looking straight down into water, but at sunset the lake becomes a perfect mirror?
facts: At steep angles, water reflects only ~2% of light - you see through clearly
At shallow angles (sunset view), water reflects over 50% - it becomes mirror-like
This is why sunset photos over water create stunning reflections

diy.title: Angle-Dependent Reflection
materials: A glass of water or clear glass panel

Gradually decrease the angle (more grazing)

diy.observation: Near-horizontal angles (80-85°) show dramatic reflections while looking straight down shows almost none - exactly as Fresnel equations predict.

lifeScene.title: How Photographers Eliminate Reflections
lifeScene.imageAlt: Before/after comparison of window photography: with glare vs clean shot through glass using polarizing filter
lifeScene.hook: Ever tried to photograph something through a window and got nothing but glare? Professional photographers have a simple solution - the polarizing filter!
facts: At Brewster's angle (~53° for water, ~56° for glass), reflected light is 100% polarized
A simple polarizing filter can completely eliminate this glare
This is why polarized sunglasses reduce water glare so effectively when fishing

physics.principle: Brewster's angle is the incident angle where p-polarization reflectance is zero
details: At this angle, reflected light is completely s-polarized
Refracted and reflected rays are perpendicular
For glass, Brewster's angle is about 56.3°

experiment.title: Brewster's Angle Polarization Experiment
experiment.example: Observing polarized reflection from water surface

diy.title: Eliminate Water Glare
materials: A bowl or tray of water
Small objects to place at the bottom

diy.observation: At Brewster's angle, the glare is completely polarized. Your polarized sunglasses block this exact polarization, revealing the objects below!

lifeScene.imageAlt: Polarimeter device measuring sugar concentration in a tube of honey solution with digital readout
lifeScene.hook: How do food scientists quickly measure sugar content without tasting? They shine polarized light through it!
facts: Sugar molecules are 'handed' - they twist light in a specific direction
More sugar = more twist. Scientists measure the angle to calculate concentration
This is how honey authenticity is verified - fake honey has the wrong rotation!

physics.principle: Chiral molecules rotate the polarization plane of linearly polarized light

diy.title: Sugar Solution Light Twister

steps: Set up polarizers on each side of the container
Fill with water first - adjust polarizers to block light (crossed)

diy.observation: Sugar molecules are chiral (like your hands - mirror images that aren't identical). They rotate light's polarization plane, letting it pass through the second polarizer.

lifeScene.imageAlt: Transparent plastic model of a bridge under stress showing rainbow-colored stress patterns between crossed polarizers
lifeScene.hook: How do engineers 'see' invisible forces inside structures? They make plastic models and use polarized light to reveal stress!
facts: Stress makes normally isotropic plastic become birefringent - it creates different refractive indices in different directions
The rainbow patterns you see show where stress is concentrated in the material
This technique helped design everything from aircraft wings to prosthetic limbs

physics.principle: Anisotropic materials have refractive indices that depend on the direction of light propagation and polarization
details: Isotropic materials: same properties in all directions (glass, water)
Uniaxial crystals: one optic axis, two principal indices (calcite, quartz)
Biaxial crystals: two optic axes, three principal indices (mica)

diy.observation: When plastic is stressed, it becomes anisotropic - light polarized in different directions travels at different speeds. This creates interference colors that reveal the stress distribution.

lifeScene.title: Why Clouds Are White, Not Blue
lifeScene.imageAlt: Fluffy white clouds against bright blue sky, illustrating the contrast between Mie and Rayleigh scattering
lifeScene.hook: If the sky is blue because of scattering, why aren't clouds blue too? The answer lies in water droplet size!
facts: Cloud droplets are much larger than air molecules - they scatter all colors equally
This equal scattering produces white (all colors combined)
Fog, mist, and haze work the same way - that's why visibility is reduced in all colors

physics.principle: When particle size is comparable to wavelength, scattering intensity has complex wavelength dependence

diy.observation: Few milk fat globules = blue scattering (like sky). Many globules = white scattering (like clouds). You've created both atmospheric effects in a glass!

lifeScene.title: The Sunset Mystery Solved
lifeScene.imageAlt: Beautiful orange-red sunset with sun on horizon, showing how light passes through more atmosphere
lifeScene.hook: Why does the sky change from blue to orange and red as the sun sets? It's all about how far light travels through the atmosphere!
facts: Blue light scatters ~10x more than red light (that's the 1/λ⁴ law)
At sunset, light travels through more atmosphere, scattering away all the blue
Mars has a different atmosphere - its sky is butterscotch colored and sunsets are blue!

physics.principle: When particle size is much smaller than wavelength, scattering intensity is proportional to λ⁻⁴
details: Short wavelength (blue light) scatters more strongly
This is why the sky appears blue

details: Remove atmospheric scattering effects
Obtain true surface reflectance
Improve remote sensing image quality

diy.title: Sunset in a Glass
materials: Large clear container or fish tank
Few drops of milk or a pinch of flour
steps: Fill container with water, add tiny amount of milk (very little!)
Shine light from one end
Look from the side - the water glows blue!
Look from the far end (through the water) - the light appears orange-red, just like sunset!
diy.observation: You've created an atmospheric model! Blue scatters sideways (daytime sky), while red passes through (sunset effect). The longer the path, the redder it gets.

stokes.title: Stokes Vector
stokes.description: Four parameters to completely describe light's polarization state
stokes.demoSubtitle: Stokes Vector - Complete Mathematical Description of Polarization State

questions.leading: How can just four numbers tell us everything about light's polarization state - including partially polarized light?
guided: What does each of the four Stokes parameters represent?
How can you measure the Stokes parameters experimentally?
openEnded: Why is a mathematical description like Stokes vectors important for polarization analysis?
How might Stokes parameters be used in astronomical observations?

physics.principle: Stokes vector uses four parameters to completely describe polarization state
details: S₀: Total intensity
S₁: Horizontal vs vertical polarization
S₂: +45° vs -45° polarization
S₃: Right vs left circular polarization

experiment.title: Stokes Parameter Measurement
experiment.example: Four measurements to determine polarization state
details: Use rotating analyzer for measurement
Combined with wave plate to measure circular component
Can measure any polarization state

frontier.title: Polarization Remote Sensing
details: Measure surface polarization characteristics
Distinguish water, vegetation, buildings
Atmospheric aerosol retrieval

lifeScene.title: How NASA Sees Through Haze
lifeScene.imageAlt: Satellite polarization image showing clear distinction between water, vegetation, and urban areas despite atmospheric haze
lifeScene.hook: Satellites can see through haze and smog to map the Earth's surface - but only with polarization! Just four numbers reveal everything.
facts: The Stokes vector is the 'fingerprint' of light - it completely describes its polarization
Different surfaces (water, leaves, concrete) have unique polarization signatures
Astronomers use Stokes vectors to study magnetic fields in distant stars

diy.title: Polarization State Detective
materials: Light source (phone screen with white background)
Piece of paper to record angles
steps: Hold the polarizer to the light and rotate it slowly
Note the angle where light is brightest - this tells you about S₁
For S₃ (circular), you'd need a quarter-wave plate before the polarizer
Different light sources have different 'signatures'!
diy.observation: By measuring at 0°, 45°, 90°, and with a wave plate, you can determine all four Stokes parameters. This is exactly how professional polarimeters work!

mueller.title: Mueller Matrix
mueller.description: 4×4 matrix describing optical element's transformation of polarization state
mueller.demoSubtitle: Mueller Matrix - Polarization Transformation of Optical Elements

questions.leading: How can a simple 4×4 matrix predict exactly what any optical element will do to light's polarization?
guided: How does the Mueller matrix relate input and output polarization states?
What is the advantage of using matrices to describe optical systems?
openEnded: How is Mueller matrix imaging used in medical diagnostics?
Could you predict the output of a complex optical system by multiplying Mueller matrices?

physics.principle: Mueller matrix describes an optical element's transformation of polarization state
details: 4×4 matrix describes linear transformation
Can cascade multiple optical elements
Contains 16 independent parameters

experiment.title: Optical Element Mueller Matrix Measurement
experiment.example: Measuring Mueller matrix of a polarizer
details: Use polarization state generator
Measure multiple input-output pairs
Retrieve Mueller matrix

frontier.title: Biomedical Imaging
details: Early skin cancer screening
Retinal lesion detection
Quantitative tissue structure analysis

lifeScene.title: Detecting Cancer with Light
lifeScene.imageAlt: Medical polarization imaging showing healthy tissue vs cancerous tissue with different Mueller matrix signatures
lifeScene.hook: Doctors are now using polarized light to detect skin cancer earlier than ever before - by measuring how tissue changes light's polarization!
facts: Healthy and cancerous tissues have different Mueller matrices - they transform light differently
This non-invasive technique can spot cancer that's invisible to the naked eye
The same math is used in designing camera lenses and fiber optic systems

diy.title: Build a Polarization System
steps: Stack polarizers at different angles and predict output using matrices
A polarizer at 0° has a specific 4×4 matrix you can look up
Multiply the matrices in reverse order: light hits the last element first!
Compare your calculation with what you observe
diy.observation: Matrix multiplication correctly predicts the output! This is how optical engineers design complex systems - they simulate before building.

ui.functionDesc: Describes linear transformation of polarization state

basics.title: Optical Basics
basics.description: Fundamental concepts of light and electromagnetic waves

lightWave.title: Light as Electromagnetic Wave
lightWave.description: Understanding light as transverse electromagnetic waves

lifeScene.title: The Wave That Needs Nothing to Ripple
lifeScene.imageAlt: Comparison of water waves needing water vs light waves traveling through empty space from the sun
lifeScene.hook: Water waves need water. Sound waves need air. But light travels through 150 million km of empty space from the sun to your eyes. How?
facts: Light is electromagnetic - it creates the medium it travels through by oscillating electric and magnetic fields
Different wavelengths (colors) are produced by different oscillation frequencies
Your microwave, WiFi, and X-rays are all light - just invisible wavelengths!

physics.principle: Light is a transverse electromagnetic wave with oscillating electric and magnetic fields perpendicular to propagation direction
details: Electric and magnetic fields oscillate perpendicular to each other
Light travels at c = 3×10⁸ m/s in vacuum
Wavelength determines color (400-700nm for visible light)

questions.leading: What exactly is 'waving' when we call light a wave - and what determines its color?
guided: What relationship exists between the electric and magnetic fields in light?
How does changing wavelength affect what we see?
openEnded: Why do you think light can travel through vacuum while sound cannot?
How might the wave nature of light explain phenomena like rainbows?

diy.title: See the Wave Nature of Light
materials: CD or DVD (old scratched ones work great)
steps: Hold the CD at an angle to the light source
Observe the rainbow patterns on the surface
Tilt the CD and watch colors shift and move
Notice how different angles show different colors
diy.observation: The tiny grooves on the CD act like a diffraction grating, spreading light into colors based on wavelength. This proves light is a wave - only waves diffract!

polarizationIntro.title: What is Polarization?
polarizationIntro.description: Introduction to the concept of light polarization

lifeScene.title: The Secret of Polarized Sunglasses
lifeScene.imageAlt: Split view of fishing scene: left side with regular glasses showing water glare, right side with polarized glasses showing fish clearly
lifeScene.hook: Ever wonder why some sunglasses let you see fish beneath water's surface while others just make everything darker?
facts: Light from the sun vibrates in all directions - it's 'unpolarized'
When it reflects off water, it becomes mostly horizontally polarized
Polarized sunglasses block horizontal vibrations - eliminating glare while letting other light through!

physics.principle: Polarization describes the orientation of the electric field oscillation in a light wave
details: Unpolarized light has random electric field orientations
Polarized light has a definite oscillation pattern
Types: linear, circular, and elliptical polarization

questions.leading: What hidden property of light do polarized sunglasses reveal - and why does it help reduce glare?
guided: What is the difference between polarized and unpolarized light?
Which direction does the electric field vibrate in polarized light?
openEnded: Why do polarized sunglasses reduce glare better than regular sunglasses?
Where might you encounter polarized light in daily life?

diy.title: Test Your Sunglasses
materials: Your sunglasses (to test if they're polarized)
A computer or phone screen (LCD type)
A reflective surface like a car hood or water
steps: Look at your phone screen through the glasses normally
Tilt your head (rotate the glasses) 90 degrees while looking
If the screen goes dark when tilted, your glasses are polarized!
Bonus: Look at water glare through them and rotate - watch glare vanish
diy.observation: LCD screens emit polarized light. Polarized sunglasses only pass one orientation - that's why tilting makes it dark. Cheap sunglasses are just tinted, so tilting doesn't change anything.

polarizationTypes.title: Types of Polarization
polarizationTypes.description: Linear, circular, and elliptical polarization explained

lifeScene.title: Why Modern 3D Beats Old 3D
lifeScene.imageAlt: Comparison of old red-blue anaglyph 3D glasses vs modern circular polarization 3D glasses at a movie theater
lifeScene.hook: Remember those old red-blue 3D glasses that gave headaches? Modern 3D uses 'spinning' light instead - and that's why it looks so much better!
facts: Old 3D used color filters - that's why you saw weird colors and got eye strain
Modern 3D uses circular polarization - left eye gets clockwise-spinning light, right eye gets counter-clockwise
Satellite communications also use circular polarization - rain doesn't disrupt it like linear would

physics.principle: Different polarization types arise from the phase and amplitude relationship of orthogonal field components
details: Linear: E-field oscillates in a single plane
Circular: E-field rotates with constant magnitude
Elliptical: E-field traces an ellipse (most general case)

questions.leading: Can light vibrate in a straight line, spin in a circle, or trace an ellipse - and what determines which pattern it follows?
guided: What determines whether light is linearly, circularly, or elliptically polarized?
How do the two orthogonal field components combine to create different polarization states?
openEnded: Why might circular polarization be useful for 3D movies?
Can you think of a real-world application that benefits from elliptical polarization?

diy.title: Identify Circular vs Linear
materials: RealD 3D glasses from a movie theater
Linear polarizer (from old LCD screen or cheap sunglasses)
steps: Look at a reflection through the linear polarizer and rotate it - reflection dims and brightens
Now look at the same reflection through 3D glasses - rotating doesn't change brightness much!
This is because 3D glasses use circular polarization, which isn't blocked by rotation
diy.observation: Linear polarization has an 'up-down' direction that rotating polarizers can block. Circular polarization 'spins', so there's no fixed direction to block - that's why head tilting doesn't ruin 3D movies!

opticalBench.title: Interactive Optical Bench
opticalBench.description: Hands-on exploration of light propagation through optical components

lifeScene.title: The Mysterious Third Polarizer
lifeScene.imageAlt: Diagram showing two crossed polarizers blocking all light, then a third polarizer at 45° in between allowing light through
lifeScene.hook: Two polarizers at 90° block ALL light. But add a third polarizer in between and suddenly light gets through! How is that possible?
facts: This seems to break the rules - blocked light magically passes through!
The secret: the middle polarizer 'rotates' the polarization in two steps instead of one blocked jump
This 'paradox' is actually how some privacy screens on ATMs work

physics.principle: Explore how light interacts with polarizers following Malus's Law
details: Adjust emitter polarization angle
Rotate polarizer to observe intensity changes
Real-time visualization of transmitted light

questions.leading: What happens when you place two polarizers at right angles - and can you let light through by adding a third one?
guided: What happens to light intensity when polarization angle differs from the polarizer axis?
At what angle difference does light get completely blocked?
openEnded: How could you use multiple polarizers to control light intensity precisely?
What practical devices use this principle of polarization filtering?

diy.title: The Three-Polarizer Trick
materials: Three polarizing filters (from multiple pairs of 3D glasses)
steps: Align two polarizers parallel - light passes through
Rotate one to 90° - light is completely blocked (crossed polarizers)
Now insert the third polarizer between them at 45°
Light magically appears! Try other angles too.
diy.observation: At 45°, 25% of light gets through (cos²45° × cos²45° = 0.25). The middle filter doesn't 'unblock' - it rotates the polarization partway, letting some through each filter!

emWaveDetails: Light is an EM wave composed of oscillating E and B fields
E and B are perpendicular to each other and to propagation direction
Travels at c = 3×10⁸ m/s in vacuum
transverseDetails: Natural light has E vibrating in random directions
Polarized light has E vibrating in specific plane

polarizationIntro.polarizedDesc: E-field vibrates in a single plane
unpolarizedDetails: E-field direction changes randomly with time
Sunlight and incandescent light are unpolarized
Can be converted to polarized by polarizer
polarizedDetails: E-field vibrates in a single plane

polarizationTypes.linearDesc: E-field vibrates along a line, δ = 0° or 180°. Most common.
polarizationTypes.circularDesc: E-field rotates in a circle, δ = ±90° and Ex = Ey. Two types.
polarizationTypes.ellipticalDesc: E-field traces an ellipse. Most general case.
polarizationTypes.linearPhysics: Ex and Ey vibrate in phase, δ = 0° or 180°
polarizationTypes.circularPhysics: Ex and Ey equal amplitude, δ = ±90°
polarizationTypes.ellipticalPhysics: Ex and Ey unequal amplitude or arbitrary phase

malus.title: Malus's Law Interactive Demo
malus.subtitle: I = I₀ · cos²θ — Transmitted intensity vs. angle between polarization and analyzer
malus.curveDesc: X-axis: angle θ (0°–180°), Y-axis: transmission ratio I/I₀. Red dot shows current position.
malus.explanation0: Two polarizers are nearly parallel, transmitted intensity ≈ I₀, almost no loss.
malus.explanation90: Two polarizers nearly crossed (90°), transmitted intensity → 0, almost no light.
malus.explanation45: When θ ≈ 45°, cos²θ ≈ 0.5, transmitted intensity is about half of I₀.
malus.explanationOther: As θ increases from 0°→90°, intensity decreases; from 90°→180° it increases again.
malus.tip: Try guessing intensity at θ=0°, 45°, 90° first, then verify by dragging slider.
malus.assumption: Assumes incident light is fully linearly polarized and polarizer is ideal.
malus.malusDesc: When linearly polarized light passes through a polarizer, I = I₀cos²θ.

brewster.title: Brewster's Angle Interactive Demo
brewster.subtitle: tan(θB) = n₂/n₁ — At this angle, reflected light is fully s-polarized
brewster.chartDesc: At Brewster's angle, Rp=0, polarization degree reaches 100% (fully s-polarized).
brewster.brewsterDesc: When incident angle equals Brewster's angle, reflected and refracted are perpendicular, p-pol reflectance is zero.
brewster.physicalDesc: At Brewster's angle, oscillating charges in refracted beam are parallel to reflection direction, cannot radiate effectively.

opticalRotation.title: Optical Rotation Interactive Demo
opticalRotation.subtitle: α = [α] × c × L — Exploring rotation effect of chiral substances on polarization plane
opticalRotation.principleDesc: Chiral molecules have non-superimposable mirror images, rotating polarization plane. Dextro (d/+) is clockwise, levo (l/-) is counterclockwise.
opticalRotation.specificRotationDesc: [α] is a characteristic constant of the substance, defined as rotation at unit concentration (1 g/mL) and unit path (1 dm). Depends on wavelength and temperature.
